unnormalised: The Indian banking sector has witnessed a significant transformation in recent years, driven by technological advancements and evolving consumer preferences. While digital transactions are on the rise, cash transactions and banking operations involving physical currency remain integral to the Indian economy, particularly in rural and semi-urban areas. Understanding the nuances of currency handling within the banking framework is crucial for maintaining financial stability and promoting inclusive growth.

unnormalised: One of the fundamental aspects of banking and cash transactions is the deposit and withdrawal of funds. Customers can deposit cash at bank branches, ATMs, and through cash deposit machines. Banks are mandated to verify the authenticity of currency notes, and any counterfeit currency detected is impounded as per RBI guidelines. Similarly, cash withdrawals can be made via ATMs, branch tellers, and increasingly, through micro-ATMs operated by banking correspondents in remote locations. A transaction limit is often set at Rs. 20,000 per day for cash withdrawals at most ATMs.
normalised: One of the fundamental aspects of banking and cash transactions is the deposit and withdrawal of funds. Customers can deposit cash at bank branches, A-T-M-s, and through cash deposit machines. Banks are mandated to verify the authenticity of currency notes, and any counterfeit currency detected is impounded as per R-B-I guidelines. Similarly, cash withdrawals can be made via A-T-M-s, branch tellers, and increasingly, through micro A-T-M-s operated by banking correspondents in remote locations. A transaction limit is often set at rupees twenty thousand per day for cash withdrawals at most A-T-M-s.

unnormalised: Remittances form a significant portion of banking transactions, especially for migrant workers sending money to their families. NEFT (National Electronic Funds Transfer) and RTGS (Real Time Gross Settlement) are commonly used for larger transfers, while UPI (Unified Payments Interface) has gained immense popularity for smaller transactions. However, cash-based remittances remain prevalent, especially through money transfer agencies. The fee for remitting Rs. 5000 through these channels can vary from Rs. 50 to Rs. 200, depending on the service provider and the distance of the remittance.
normalised: Remittances form a significant portion of banking transactions, especially for migrant workers sending money to their families. N-E-F-T (National Electronic Funds Transfer) and R-T-G-S (Real Time Gross Settlement) are commonly used for larger transfers, while U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) has gained immense popularity for smaller transactions. However, cash-based remittances remain prevalent, especially through money transfer agencies. The fee for remitting rupees five thousand through these channels can vary from rupees fifty to rupees two hundred, depending on the service provider and the distance of the remittance.

unnormalised: Loan disbursements and repayments also involve substantial cash transactions, especially in sectors like agriculture and small businesses. While banks encourage digital transfers, many borrowers prefer receiving and repaying loans in cash due to convenience and lack of digital literacy. Microfinance institutions (MFIs) often handle large volumes of cash for loan disbursements and collections. The interest rate on a microfinance loan of Rs. 10,000 can range from 22% to 26% per annum.

The interest rate on a microfinance loan of rupees ten thousand can range from twenty two percent to twenty six percent per annum.

unnormalised: Currency exchange is another key area of banking and cash transactions. Banks facilitate the exchange of Indian Rupees (INR) for foreign currencies and vice versa. The exchange rates are determined by market forces, and banks typically charge a commission for the service. For example, exchanging $100 USD for INR might involve a commission of 2%, in addition to the prevailing exchange rate, which was around ₹83.50 per USD on 20/10/2024.

For example, exchanging dollar one hundred U-S-D for I-N-R might involve a commission of two percent, in addition to the prevailing exchange rate, which was around rupees eighty three point fifty per U-S-D on twentieth october two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: The management of currency in circulation is a critical responsibility of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The RBI ensures the availability of adequate currency notes and coins to meet the demands of the economy. Banks act as intermediaries in this process, receiving currency from the RBI and distributing it to the public through their branches and ATMs. Banks also deposit surplus cash with the RBI to maintain optimal liquidity. ATMs are typically filled with denominations of ₹500, ₹200, and ₹100 notes.
normalised: The management of currency in circulation is a critical responsibility of the Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I). The R-B-I ensures the availability of adequate currency notes and coins to meet the demands of the economy. Banks act as intermediaries in this process, receiving currency from the R-B-I and distributing it to the public through their branches and A-T-M-s. Banks also deposit surplus cash with the R-B-I to maintain optimal liquidity. A-T-M-s are typically filled with denominations of rupees five hundred, rupees two hundred, and rupees one hundred notes.

unnormalised: Finally, the security of cash transactions is paramount. Banks employ various measures to safeguard currency from theft and fraud, including surveillance systems, armed guards, and cash management protocols. They also educate customers about safe banking practices and encourage them to use digital payment methods wherever possible. Incidents of ATM skimming and cash theft are regularly reported, highlighting the ongoing need for vigilance and enhanced security measures. The maximum insurance claim on stolen cash from an ATM is usually limited to Rs. 50,000.
